prompt: If region x is NW of region y and region y is NW of region z, then which could be the possible relations between region x and region z?
answer:
Looking at the definitions and constraints:

When region x is NW of region y, this means:
- supx(x) ≤ infx(y) (x is entirely to the west of y)
- supy(y) ≤ infy(x) (x is entirely to the north of y)

Similarly, when region y is NW of region z:
- supx(y) ≤ infx(z) (y is entirely to the west of z)
- supy(z) ≤ infy(y) (y is entirely to the north of z)

Through transitivity:
- supx(x) ≤ infx(y) ≤ supx(y) ≤ infx(z), therefore supx(x) ≤ infx(z)
- supy(z) ≤ infy(y) ≤ supy(y) ≤ infy(x), therefore supy(z) ≤ infy(x)

These derived constraints (supx(x) ≤ infx(z) and supy(z) ≤ infy(x)) exactly match the definition of the NW relation.

None of the other cardinal directions (N, NE, E, SE, S, SW, W, B) are possible because they would require conditions that contradict our derived constraints.

Therefore, the only possible relation between region x and region z is NW.
